channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Trump shrinks National Security Council in major foreign policy shakeup
item.description: The NSC has traditionally played a pivotal role in advising the president for his biggest diplomatic and security decisions. But in Trump's second term, it has seen its influence shrink.
item.content:encoded:
The NSC has traditionally played a pivotal role in advising the president for his biggest diplomatic and security decisions. But in Trump's second term, it has seen its influence shrink.

(Image credit: Saul Loeb)
item.dc:creator: Tom Bowman

item.title: Backyard feeders changed the shape of hummingbird beaks, scientists say
item.description: A new study details the evolutionary change of Anna's Hummingbirds, finding their beaks have grown longer and more tapered to get the most from common feeders.
item.content:encoded:
A new study details the evolutionary change of Anna's Hummingbirds, finding their beaks have grown longer and more tapered to get the most from common feeders.

(Image credit: ROBYN BECK/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Kat Lonsdorf

item.title: Can Trump suspend habeas corpus?
item.description:
Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem got a pop quiz at a senate hearing this week. The question came from Democratic Senator Maggie Hassan, of New Hampshire.

Hassan asked Noem to to explain habeas corpus.

For the record, habeas corpus is the legal principle, enshrined in the Constitution, that protects people from illegal detention.

The reason that this bit of Latin is under discussion – is because the Trump administration says it's considering suspending habeas corpus.

This core constitutional protection has been an obstacle to the President's mass deportation plan.

Habeas corpus is a principle that's hundreds of years older than America itself.

What would it mean if the President suspended it? And could he, under the Constitution?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem got a pop quiz at a senate hearing this week. The question came from Democratic Senator Maggie Hassan, of New Hampshire.

Hassan asked Noem to to explain habeas corpus.

For the record, habeas corpus is the legal principle, enshrined in the Constitution, that protects people from illegal detention.

The reason that this bit of Latin is under discussion – is because the Trump administration says it's considering suspending habeas corpus.

This core constitutional protection has been an obstacle to the President's mass deportation plan.

Habeas corpus is a principle that's hundreds of years older than America itself.

What would it mean if the President suspended it? And could he, under the Constitution?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

item.title: Cold case solved: College students help ID the remains of a 19th century sea captain
item.description: Remains of the "Scattered Man John Doe" began washing ashore in New Jersey in 1995 and went unidentified for the next three decades. Students at Ramapo College set about to solve the mystery.
item.content:encoded:
Remains of the "Scattered Man John Doe" began washing ashore in New Jersey in 1995 and went unidentified for the next three decades. Students at Ramapo College set about to solve the mystery.

(Image credit: Jessica Kourkounis)
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: Trump seeks to boost nuclear industry and overhaul safety regulator
item.description: A series of executive orders aims to promote new kinds of nuclear reactors while restructuring the body in charge of nuclear safety.
item.content:encoded:
A series of executive orders aims to promote new kinds of nuclear reactors while restructuring the body in charge of nuclear safety.

(Image credit: Mike Stewart)
item.dc:creator: Geoff Brumfiel

item.title: DOJ confirms it has a deal with Boeing to drop prosecution over deadly 737 Max crashes
item.description: The Justice Department says it has reached an agreement in principle with Boeing to drop a criminal case over two fatal crashes of 737 Max jets, despite objections from some victims' family members.
item.content:encoded:
The Justice Department says it has reached an agreement in principle with Boeing to drop a criminal case over two fatal crashes of 737 Max jets, despite objections from some victims' family members.

(Image credit: Shelby Tauber)
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose

item.title: Inside a Drone Factory in Ukraine
item.description: Throughout the more than three years since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, drones have been a key tool and weapon used by both sides in the conflict. Because of this, Ukraine is at the cutting edge of drone innovation, churning out some two million unmanned aerial vehicles, or UAVs, last year. These flying drones come in all sizes and they're produced in factories large and high-tech, as well as small and shoestring. In today's episode, NPR's Eleanor Beardsley takes us inside a drone-making operation in Kyiv.
item.content:encoded: Throughout the more than three years since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, drones have been a key tool and weapon used by both sides in the conflict. Because of this, Ukraine is at the cutting edge of drone innovation, churning out some two million unmanned aerial vehicles, or UAVs, last year. These flying drones come in all sizes and they're produced in factories large and high-tech, as well as small and shoestring. In today's episode, NPR's Eleanor Beardsley takes us inside a drone-making operation in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Beardsley

item.title: DOGE created a 'survey of surveys' for a push to cut some government data collection
item.description: DOGE's push to cut some federal surveys conducted by the Census Bureau may be duplicating a White House agency's oversight work and weaken U.S. data infrastructure, experts warn.
item.content:encoded:
DOGE's push to cut some federal surveys conducted by the Census Bureau may be duplicating a White House agency's oversight work and weaken U.S. data infrastructure, experts warn.

(Image credit: Etienne Laurent)
item.dc:creator: Hansi Lo Wang

item.title: Fired Copyright Office head sues Trump administration over removal
item.description: Shira Perlmutter's termination came shortly after the Copyright Office published a long-anticipated report on artificial intelligence.
item.content:encoded:
Shira Perlmutter's termination came shortly after the Copyright Office published a long-anticipated report on artificial intelligence.

(Image credit: Mariam Zuhaib)
item.dc:creator: Andrew Limbong

item.title: Judge blocks Trump admin's move to bar Harvard from enrolling international students
item.description: This comes in response to a lawsuit Harvard filed on Friday morning, challenging the Trump administration's abrupt move to revoke the school's ability to enroll foreign students.
item.content:encoded:
This comes in response to a lawsuit Harvard filed on Friday morning, challenging the Trump administration's abrupt move to revoke the school's ability to enroll foreign students.

(Image credit: Kyle Mazza)
item.dc:creator: Janet W. Lee
